title-group.article-title: Double Roots of [-1, 1] Power Series and Related Matters

abstract.p: For a given collection of distinct arguments <tex-math>$\overrightarrow{\theta} = (\theta_1,..., \theta_t),$</tex-math> multiplicities <tex-math>$\overrightarrow{k} = (k_1,..., k_t),$</tex-math> and a real interval I = [U, V] containing zero, we are interested in determining the smallest r for which there is a power series f(x) = 1 + ∑<sup>∞</sup><sub>n=1</sub> a<sub>n</sub> x<sup>n</sup> with coefficients a<sub>n</sub> in I, and roots α<sub>1</sub> = re<sup>2π iθ<sub>1</sub></sup>,..., α<sub>t</sub> = re<sup>2π iθ<sub>t</sub></sup> of order k<sub>1</sub>,..., k<sub>t</sub> respectively. <tex-math>$We denote this by r(\overrightarrow{\theta}, \overrightarrow{k}; I).$</tex-math> We describe the usual form of the extremal series (we give a sufficient condition which is also necessary when the extremal series possesses at least (∑<sup>t</sup><sub>i=1</sub> δ (θ<sub>i</sub>)k<sub>i</sub>) - 1 non-dependent coefficients strictly inside I, where δ(θ<sub>i</sub>) is 1 or 2 as α<sub>i</sub> is real or complex). We focus particularly on r(θ, 2; [-1, 1]), the size of the smallest double root of a [-1, 1] power series lying on a given ray (of interest in connection with the complex analogue of work of Boris Solomyak on the distribution of the random series ∑±λ<sup>n</sup>). We computed the value of r(θ, 2; [-1, 1]) for the rationals θ in (0, 1/2) of denominator less than fifty. The smallest value we encountered was r(4/29, 2; [-1, 1]) = 0.7536065594.... For the one-sided intervals I = [0, 1] and [-1, 0] the corresponding smallest values were r(11/30, 2; [0, 1]) = .8237251991... and r(1/3, 2; [-1, 0]) = .8656332072....
